intro: Tapinanthus ophiodes, commonly known as the parasitic dodder, is a hemiparasitic plant that relies on host plants for water and nutrients. It produces small, yellowish flowers and has a highly branched, thread-like stem covered in tiny, sticky seeds. The plant is often found in arid or semi-arid regions, attaching itself to a variety of host species. Its life cycle involves germinating near a host and then establishing a connection through specialized roots. Due to its parasitic nature, it can significantly weaken or even kill its host plants.
